prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Special color-changing cloth belonging to Scone. She has lost a roll of it, along with the device that powers it.
Evidence 10
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 11
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 12
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 13
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures in the finals were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 14
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 15
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 16
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 17
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 18
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 19
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 20
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 21
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 22
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 23
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 24
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 25
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 26
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 27
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 28
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 29
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 30
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 31
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 32
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 33
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 34
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case. [info] Detected: Salt, Sugar, Blood

Sugar composition matches that of sugar found in the pale blue liquid in Artie Frost's room eighteen years ago.

Sugar detected in fountain water also seems to be a match.
Evidence 35
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 36
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes. [info] There are several conditions under which the time limit can be put on hold and extended:
If a suspect goes to a foreign country, then the time limit is put on hold until they return.
If any possible accomplices are put on trial, then the time limit is put on hold until the accomplice's verdict is reached.
If charges are pressed to demand compensation, then the time limit is put on hold until this procedure is cleared up.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: Gusto and Frost's relationship?
Person: von Karma
Testimony 1
Testimony: It's obvious the only relationship they had was that they happened to participate in the same contest.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, let's tackle this problem. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. 

First, I'll look at the testimonies. Testimony 0 is by von Karma, who says that Gusto and Frost only had a relationship in participating in the same contest. Testimony 1 from von Karma adds that their relationship was purely coincidental, just being in the same contest.

Now, looking at the evidence, Evidence 34 is the Gemini Case Analysis Results. It states that sugar from Frost's room matched the sugar in the fountain water. This suggests a deeper connection between Frost and Gusto, possibly indicating a shared secret or history, which contradicts von Karma's testimony that their relationship was only due to the contest.

So, the contradiction is between Evidence 34 and Testimony 1.
</think>

If a suspect goes to a foreign country, then the time limit is put on hold until they return.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: If you want to know about Gusto and Frost's connection so badly, I'll tell you.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 1
Testimony: Last night, when I interrogated Gusto, he told me about his connection with Frost.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 2
Testimony: Until the day before the finals, they worked on their desserts together.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 3
Testimony: Why? Because Gusto had poor design sense, and Frost was a novice at baking.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 4
Testimony: Their cooperation lasted only through the semifinals. For the finals, they were on their own.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let's start by understanding the situation.

We have a murder case involving several characters, and there are a bunch of pieces of evidence and testimonies provided. My task is to find one pair where an evidence and a testimony contradict each other.

First, I'll go through the evidence list to understand what each piece says. Then, I'll look at the testimonies to see what the characters are saying. After that, I'll try to find any contradictions between them.

Looking at the evidence:

- Evidence 14: Semifinal Entries. It says that Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs but tasted the same.
- Evidence 34: Gemini Case Analysis Results. This one mentions that sugar detected in the fountain water matches the sugar found in Frost's room eighteen years ago.

Now, looking at the testimonies from von Karma:

- Testimony 3: von Karma says that Gusto had poor design sense and Frost was a novice at baking, so they worked together until the semifinals.

Wait a minute, if Frost and Gusto were working together up until the semifinals, their semifinal entries should reflect that collaboration. But Evidence 14 says their semifinal entries had different designs. That seems contradictory because if they were collaborating, I'd expect their designs to be similar or at least influenced by each other, not different.

Also, von Karma's testimony implies that their teamwork stopped after the semifinals, which makes sense if their designs diverged in the finals. But the key point is the semifinal entries having different designs despite their supposed collaboration.

So, the contradiction is between Evidence 14 and von Karma's Testimony 3. The evidence shows different designs in their semifinal entries, while the testimony claims they were working together up until then, which would likely result in more similar designs.

Another point to consider is the sugar composition in Evidence 34. It matches sugar from Frost's room, suggesting a link to the victim's past. However, von Karma's testimony doesn't mention anything about this, so it doesn't directly contradict.

Therefore, the main contradiction is between Evidence 14 and von Karma's Testimony 3 regarding the designs of their semifinal entries.
</think>

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: 18 years after Monsieur Master was arrested, I was finally able to buy back this mansion.
Person: Kate
Testimony 1
Testimony: Then, in order to maintain it, I decided to manage it as an art gallery.
Person: Kate
Testimony 2
Testimony: I collected Pierre Hoquet's works from all over the world.
Person: Kate
Testimony 3
Testimony: After all, it was my dream to open the Zodiac Art Gallery.
Person: Kate
Testimony 4
Testimony: I prepared replicas of the sculptures in the Winter Palace based on the photos I took.
Person: Kate

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me go through everything step by step.

First, I'll look at the characters involved. There's Kate, who owns the Zodiac Art Gallery, and she's talking about how she managed to buy back the mansion 18 years after Monsieur Master was arrested. She mentions that she collected Pierre Hoquet's works from around the world and prepared replicas of sculptures from the Winter Palace based on her photos.

Now, looking at the evidence, there's a Winter Wing Photo (Evidence 21) that shows statues matching those made by the victim, Artie Frost, eighteen years ago. This suggests that Frost's work was replicated or displayed in the gallery.

Kate's testimony (Testimony 4) specifically mentions that she prepared replicas of the sculptures in the Winter Palace based on her photos. This implies that she was involved in creating or acquiring these replicas, which would include Frost's work. However, if Frost's statues were already present in the gallery as replicas, it contradicts the idea that Frost himself created them eighteen years ago, especially if Kate is the one who prepared them.

So, the contradiction arises because if Kate prepared the replicas based on her photos, it suggests that Frost's original work wasn't in the gallery, but rather Kate's replicas were. This conflicts with the evidence that the Winter Wing Photo shows statues made by Frost eighteen years ago, implying his direct involvement in creating those pieces for the gallery.

Therefore, the evidence (Winter Wing Photo) and Kate's testimony (Testimony 4) contradict each other because one suggests Frost's original statues were there, while the other indicates Kate replicated them based on her photos.
</think>

Evidence 36
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes. [info] There are several conditions under which the time limit can be put on hold and extended:
If a suspect goes to a foreign country, then the time limit is put on hold until they return.
If any possible accomplices are put on trial, then the time limit is put on hold until the accomplice's verdict is reached.
If charges are pressed to demand compensation, then the time limit is put on hold until this procedure is cleared up.

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony to see where there's a conflict.

Looking at the evidence, I see that Evidence 14 is about the semifinal entries. It says that Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs but tasted the same. That's interesting because if they tasted the same, maybe they used similar recipes or ingredients.

Now, looking at the testimonies, Testimony 4 from Gusto says that aside from not cooperating with Sir Frost, the finals weren't much different from the semifinals. If the finals weren't much different, then perhaps their methods or ingredients were similar, which aligns with the evidence that their semifinal entries tasted the same.

But wait, Testimony 0 says that Gusto and Frost cooperated until the finals, with Gusto handling the flavor and Frost the design. So, if they were collaborating, it makes sense their semifinal entries would taste the same. However, Testimony 4 suggests that the finals weren't much different, which might imply they continued collaborating, but the evidence says their semifinal entries tasted the same. That seems consistent, so maybe there's no contradiction here.

Wait, perhaps I'm misunderstanding. Let me check again. Evidence 14 says that in the semifinals, their designs were different but the taste was the same. Testimony 4 says that the finals weren't much different from the semifinals. If the finals were similar, then their semifinal and final entries would both have the same taste but different designs. That doesn't seem contradictory.

Hmm, maybe I'm missing something. Let me think differently. If Gusto says they didn't cooperate in the finals, but the evidence shows that their semifinal entries tasted the same, maybe that implies they did cooperate in the semifinals but not in the finals. However, the evidence only talks about the semifinals, so it doesn't directly contradict the testimony about the finals.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is that if they didn't cooperate in the finals, their entries should have different tastes, but the evidence only talks about the semifinals. So maybe there's no direct contradiction. I might need to look elsewhere.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 4 says that the finals weren't much different, implying their methods or ingredients were similar, but if they didn't cooperate, their entries should have been different. However, the evidence is about the semifinals, not the finals. So perhaps there's no direct contradiction here either.

I'm a bit confused. Maybe I should look for another pair. Let's see, Evidence 34 is about the Gemini case analysis results, detecting salt, sugar, and blood. It mentions that the sugar matches what was found in Frost's room eighteen years ago and in the fountain water. Testimony 0 from Gusto talks about cooperating with Frost until the finals. If the sugar from Frost's room matches the sugar in the fountain, maybe it implies Frost was involved, but Gusto says they cooperated, so maybe there's no contradiction.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 14 and Testimony 4. Evidence 14 says that in the semifinals, their entries tasted the same but had different designs. Testimony 4 says that the finals weren't much different from the semifinals. If the finals weren't much different, then their entries in the finals would also taste the same, but if they didn't cooperate, their entries should have different tastes. That's a contradiction because if they didn't cooperate, their entries should have been different in taste, but the evidence suggests they were the same.

So, Evidence 14 and Testimony 4 contradict each other because the evidence shows their semifinal entries tasted the same, implying collaboration, while the testimony claims they didn't cooperate in the finals, suggesting their entries should have been different.
